'''''Albatrellus ovinus''''' is a [[Terrestrial animal|terrestrial]] [[polypore]] [[fungus]] found in western North America, and Northern Europe. It is very closely related to the more common ''[[Albatrellus subrubescens|A. subrubescens]]'',<ref name="pmid9342352">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hibbett DS, Pine EM, Langer E, Langer G, Donoghue MJ |title=Evolution of gilled mushrooms and puffballs inferred from ribosomal DNA sequences |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=94 |issue=22 |pages=12002–6 |year=1997|pmid=9342352 |pmc=23683 |doi= 10.1073/pnas.94.22.12002|url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9342352 |accessdate=2008-11-11}}</ref> from which it may be distinguished microscopically by the [[amyloid]] [[spore]] wall. It is edible and sold commercially in Finland.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pelkonen|first=Riina|last2=Alfthan|first2=Georg|last3=Järvinen|first3=Olli|title=Element Concentrations in Wild Edible Mushrooms in Finland|publisher=Finnish Environment Institute|location=Helsinki|year=2008|pages=32|isbn=978-952-11-3153-0|url=http://www.ymparisto.fi/download.asp?contentid=87635|accessdate=2009-02-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928125244/http://www.ymparisto.fi/download.asp?contentid=87635|archive-date=2011-09-28|url-status=dead}}</ref> Common name: Sheep Polypore.

==Similar species==
A fuller discussion of the small color differences from the inedible ''[[Albatrellus subrubescens]]'' can be found at that extensive article. Microscopically, the spores of ''A. subrubescens'' are amyloid, while the ones of ''A. ovinus'' are not.<ref>W. Julich, 1984: Die Nichtblatterpilze, Gallertpilze und Bauchpilze. Kleine Kryptogamenflora Band II Teil b/1</ref><ref>J. Breitenbach, F. Kranzlin, 1986: Pilze der Schweiz, Band 2. Nichtblatterpilze.</ref>
